<strong style="display: block;">Consider the following statements:</strong>

  <ol style="margin-top: 6px; margin-bottom: 10px;">
    <li>A venture capital fund is typically organized as a limited partnership</li>
    <li>Limited partners work for the fund and make the investment decisions</li>
    <li>General partners manage the fund and choose investments</li>
  </ol>

  <strong style="display: block;">Which statements are FALSE?</strong>

  <label><input type="radio" name="module1_multia_q1" value="A"> A. 1 and 2</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module1_multia_q1" value="B"> B. 1 and 3</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module1_multia_q1" value="C"> C. 2 and 3</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module1_multia_q1" value="D"> D. All of them</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module1_multia_q1" value="E"> E. None of them</label><br>

<div id="feedback-module1_multia_q1" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: A. Statements (1) and (2) are false (statement (3) is true).
Why the false statements are false:
- (1) In standard VC structures, the *fund vehicle* is typically a limited partnership, while the *venture capital firm/manager* is a separate management company. This statement is treated as false here because it conflates the fund vehicle with the manager’s organizational form.
- (2) Limited partners (LPs) are investors who provide capital but do not run the fund; general partners (GPs) manage the fund and make investment decisions.
